awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RUI: Chronology and Ecology of Late Pleistocene Megafauna at Rancho La Brea
awd_abstract_narration:
The Rancho La Brea tar pits of Los Angeles, California contain thousands of bones from large mammals --dire wolves, sabertooth cats, coyotes, extinct bison, horses, and others-- trapped in sticky surface oil deposits during the last Ice Age. This unparalleled fossil assemblage allows rigorous studies of extinct mammal biology, especially of carnivores which are rare at most fossil sites. The La Brea fossils span a critical time in Earth's history (approximately 50,000 years ago to the present) that includes major events such as the end of the last Ice Age, the arrival of humans in North America, and an extinction that killed two thirds of the large mammals on the continent. This unique deposit will be used to investigate relationships between major environmental changes and evolutionary variation (size, diet, etc.) in large mammals, information that is critical for promoting the survival of wildlife today. The project involves significant community outreach in the greater Los Angeles area through the Tar Pits Museum and will create educational content that will be available online for high school teachers across the country.

	The major impediment to system-level study at Rancho La Brea is a paucity of radiocarbon dates and the resulting inability to correlate biotic change with time. This project will intensively radiocarbon date samples from multiple pits spanning the last 50,000 years to establish the first detailed chronology for the entrapment of four extinct species of large mammals, and one extant species. It will involve the collection and compilation of census data for these species to track changes in total abundance and diversity, as well as data on morphological and dietary changes. A well-resolved chronology will allow these data on evolutionary changes in mammals and the Pleistocene megafaunal extinctions to be linked to existing records of major paleo-environmental changes. This work will have broad implications for our understanding of extinctions, survival, environmental variables, and humans on mammalian ecology, which is directly relevant to modern conservation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

perf_inst.perf_str_addr: Dept of Earth and Env Sci

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The La Brea Tar Pits paleontological locality in California, USA, houses the world's largest collection of Ice Age plants and animals, spanning the last 60,000 years of Earth's history. This period of time includes significant climate fluctuations, the arrival of humans in North America, and the extinction of many large mammals. Despite the wealth of specimens, the lack of chronological control over the numerous viscous deposits has impeded scientists' ability to fully understand the relationships between these phenomena and the changes in the La Brea ecosystem.

Project Goals and Achievements

  1. Develop a High-Resolution Chronology: By creating a detailed timeline for several La Brea asphalt seeps, researchers could facilitate more precise studies of these unique paleontological resources.
  2. Understand Megafaunal Responses: The project sought to analyze how large mammals at La Brea responded to late Pleistocene environmental changes, assessing their paleoecology and evolution via the study of their morphology, dental microwear textures, dental mesowear, and stable isotopes from their teeth and bones.

To accomplish these goals, we radiocarbon dated over 400 jaw bones from five species of La Brea megafauna: sabertoothed cats, dire wolves, extinct horses, extinct bison, and coyotes. By dating only jaw bones, we ensured that each date represented a different animal, allowing for accurate comparisons with associated paleoecological data.

The project successfully constrained the ages of five "tar pit" deposits spanning the last 40,000 years (Pits 3, 10, 13, 61/67, and 91) and compared the morphology and ecology of the five megafaunal species over time and with modern taxa, when relevant. This significant advancement will enhance researchers' ability to reconstruct past ecosystems in this region and trace their evolution over time. We discovered changes in megafaunal diet and body size, and observed shifts in the ecological community composition during late-Pleistocene climate change. Notably, we pinpointed the timing of local extinctions of several megafaunal species in southern California and correlated these events with climate changes, regional plant community shifts, and human population movements. This discovery represents a major advance in understanding the Ice Age megafaunal extinction event and the intersection of climate change and human activities in driving ecosystems to tipping points. 

Broader Impacts

Educational Outreach and Public Engagement

The project involved significant community outreach in both the greater Los Angeles area and in the larger Nashville Metropolitan area through the Tar Pits Museum and Vanderbilt University. We created educational content available online for high school teachers nationwide and engaged in various local and regional outreach activities:

  • Presentations at local public schools (career days, fourth-grade fossil week, and science camps).
  • Collaborations with the Adventure Science Center in Nashville, TN (Science Cafes, TWISTER STEM Conference for Girls in Grades 9-12).
  • Virtual presentations to online classes of elementary school students about paleontology.
  • Participation in the International Education Week: Climate Change Research Symposium at Vanderbilt University.
  • "Pleistocene Predators of the Tar Pits" (https://youtu.be/hOl4NkqxsOM)
  • "Chewing on Change" for Darwin Day Online Symposium, coordinated by the National Center for Science Education.
  • "Cautionary Conservation Lessons from the Paleontological Record" for The Royal Irish Academy Discourse Lecture Series.
  • "Ask a Vanderbilt Paleontologist" sessions and other educational videos available on YouTube.
  • TEDx Vanderbilt talk titled "Our Ancient Past is the Key to Our Future."
  • Completion of a book aimed at providing underrepresented role models in STEM fields to children.  The book is titled, I'm a Vertebrate Paleontologist Now! By Larisa DeSantis. Published June 11, 2024. World Scientific: https://doi.org/10.1142/13573. 48 pages.
  • Examples of articles about grant related research: Science (https://www.science.org/content/article/raging-wildfires-may-doomed-californias-ancient-megamammals-tar-pit-fossils-reveal); The New York Times (https://www.nytimes.com/2023/08/17/science/climate-paleontology-mammals.html)
  • See also: www.DeSantisLab.com

 

Student Involvement and Training

Nearly all data used in our research were collected in partnership with paid undergraduate interns, who were trained in all aspects of specimen-based research and led portions of the project. Some student-led studies are currently under review for publication, and many students had the opportunity to present their research at national scientific conferences. Interns were also trained in science communication and gave daily public presentations to museum visitors at La Brea Tar Pits during the summer.  This work also supported a postdoctoral researcher and a research assistant at Vanderbilt University.  Further, more than ten undergraduate students at Vanderbilt University engaged in relevant research and/or were trained on specimens from Rancho La Brea.

Collectively, the project's findings on the interplay between climate change, human activities, and megafaunal extinctions offer valuable lessons for modern conservation efforts. Our extensive outreach efforts have brought these scientific discoveries to the public, enriching educational experiences and fostering a deeper understanding of our planet's history.

 


Last Modified: 07/06/2024
Modified by: Larisa Grawe Desantis
